qas.question: How do receive information from the physical world?

answers.text: messages transmitted along the nerves to the seat of consciousness

qas.question: What type of consciousness is similar but not identical to consciousness itself?
What is the nature of the fundamental character of reality?
According to the author, who would have particular trouble in accepting that reality is fundamentally mental?
What is the main thing that we experience?
What is more general that mind-stuff of the world?

plausible_answers.text: the substratum of everything is of mental character

qas.question: What does the matter-of-fact physicist easily accept?

plausible_answers.text: the nerves to the seat of consciousness

qas.question: What is the cyclic scheme transmitted by?

context: "The mind-stuff of the world is, of course, something more general than our <b5_0>individual conscious minds<b5_0/>.... The mind-stuff is not spread <b6_0>in space and time<b6_0/>; these are part of the cyclic scheme ultimately derived out of it.... It is necessary to keep reminding ourselves that all knowledge of our environment from which the world of physics is constructed, has entered in the form of <a0_0>messages transmitted along <b9_0>the nerves to the seat of consciousness<b9_0/><a0_0/>.... <b7_0>Consciousness<b7_0/> is not sharply defined, but fades into <a1_0>subconsciousness<a1_0/>; and beyond that we must postulate something indefinite but yet continuous with our mental nature.... It is difficult for the matter-of-fact <a3_0>physicist<a3_0/> to accept the view that <b8_0>the substratum of everything is of <a2_0>mental<a2_0/> character<b8_0/>. But no one can deny that <a4_0>mind<a4_0/> is the first and most direct thing in our experience, and all else is remote inference."
